etymologies: Old English mǣl (also in the sense ‘measure’, surviving in words such as piecemeal ‘measure taken at one time’), of Germanic origin. The early sense of meal involved a notion of ‘fixed time’; compare with Dutch maal ‘meal, (portion of) time’ and German Mal ‘time’, Mahl ‘meal’, from an Indo-European root meaning ‘to measure’

definitions: any of the regular occasions in a day when a reasonably large amount of food is eaten, such as breakfast, lunch, or dinner
shortDefinitions: any of regular occasions in day when reasonably large amount of food is eaten

definitions: the food eaten on regular occasions

etymologies: Old English melu, meolo, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch meel and German Mehl, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin molere ‘to grind’

definitions: the edible part of any grain or pulse ground to powder, such as cornmeal

examples.text: she called to Judith to bring some meal for the hens

shortDefinitions: edible part of grain, ground to powder

definitions: any powdery substance made by grinding
